title: Pediatric Appendicitis
setup_script: “A 10-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with 24 hours of abdominal pain. The pain began around her umbilicus and has migrated to the right lower quadrant. She has a low-grade fever and decreased appetite. On exam, she appears uncomfortable but stable. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 110/65 mmHg, HR 105 bpm, RR 22/min, Temp 38 °C.
Tenderness at McBurney’s point with rebound and guarding; Rovsing sign positive.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks for laboratory studies
dynamic_flow.reply: WBC 15,000/µL with left shift, CRP elevated; urinalysis normal.
Noncompressible tubular structure 8 mm in diameter with periappendiceal fluid, consistent with appendicitis.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders CT scan instead
dynamic_flow.reply: CT abdomen/pelvis shows inflamed appendix with periappendiceal stranding, no perforation.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays diagnosis or management
dynamic_flow.reply: The patient’s pain worsens, fever increases to 39 °C, and she becomes tachycardic to 130 bpm.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates NPO status, IV fluids, and broad-spectrum antibiotics
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient stabilizes; antibiotics given (ceftriaxone plus metronidazole).

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults surgery for laparoscopic appendectomy
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient is scheduled for urgent operative intervention.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident inquires about intraoperative findings
dynamic_flow.reply: Appendix is inflamed but intact; no perforation.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident manages perforated appendix operatively
dynamic_flow.reply: Appendectomy performed, abdomen irrigated, and drains placed; patient taken to ICU.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident is asked to describe operative techniques
dynamic_flow.reply: Please describe the steps of a laparoscopic appendectomy in this patient.
Early ambulation, pain control, diet advancement, and discharge when tolerating oral intake.
Wound erythema noted on day 3; culture shows superficial SSI. Managed with local care and antibiotics.
Explained warning signs of complications, follow-up needs, and risk of recurrence if non-operative management had been chosen.

critical_decision_points: Evaluation of suspected appendicitis with history, physical exam, and imaging.
Initiation of NPO status, IV fluids, and antibiotics.
Decision regarding immediate surgery vs. non-operative management.
Recognition and management of perforated appendicitis.

resident_feedback_template: Strengths: You demonstrated strong diagnostic reasoning by promptly recognizing appendicitis. You prioritized resuscitation, antibiotics, and surgical consultation effectively. Communication with the patient’s family was clear and compassionate.Areas for Improvement: Consider refining decision-making around non-operative management, including discussing recurrence risk. Earlier recognition and intervention in the setting of worsening vitals would improve timeliness of care. Expand discussion of postoperative complications and ensure thorough description of operative techniques.Suggested Reading Topics: - Pediatric Appendicitis (SCORE curriculum) - Non-operative Management of Appendicitis in Children (ASE Core Curriculum) - Operative Techniques in Pediatric Appendectomy - Postoperative Care and Complications in Pediatric Surgery
